posts.name: Spencer
posts.cooked:
EXTREMLY IMPORTANTLY - DO NOT OUTPUT ANYTHING BUT THE CLEANED VERSION (NO INTRODUCTION, NO OTHER LITTLE EXPLENATION), JUST THE CLEANED PARAGRAPH. The text is:
  • We don’t use CAD.
  • We use CAD, but not Drawings.
  • We use CAD and some parts get Drawings.
  • We use CAD and every part we make gets a drawing.
0 voters

Hi all, I’m a new mentor for an FRC team that is just starting to get into using CAD to design their robot. I was wondering how other teams organize their Onshape files to be easily traceable and to make sure they contain the necessary information for use in FRC.

I’m familiar with using SolidWorks in a professional setting, however a lot of the stuff I do at work is too time-consuming and in-depth to be efficient to use for FRC, especially with limited administrators and more frequent mistakes from students.

If you’re willing, I would love a quick overview of how you organize your CAD files, how you prevent two people from building different components at the same time for the same space on the robot, and any custom (or otherwise) properties that are associated with your files (think material, revision, owner, location on robot, etc.). Also, I’d love to know which parts (if any) you make drawings for as opposed to just 3D modeling the part and making it from there.

Let me know if you have any questions or need clarification, I know this is a lot for one very broad post.

Assistant: We don’t use CAD. We use CAD but not Drawings. We use CAD and some parts get Drawings. We use CAD and every part we make gets a drawing. If you’re willing, I would love a quick overview of how you organize your CAD files, how you prevent two people from building different components at the same time for the same space on the robot, and any custom properties that are associated with your files (think material, revision, owner, location on robot, etc.). Also, I’d love to know which parts (if any) you make drawings for as opposed to just 3D modeling the part and making it from there. Let me know if you have any questions or need clarification, I know this is a lot for one very broad post.

options.html: We use CAD, but not Drawings.
We use CAD and some parts get Drawings.
We use CAD and every part we make gets a drawing.

posts.name: Calvin Selin
posts.cooked: Check out FRCDesign.org and this slideshow.

link_counts.title: Onshape Best Practices for FRC - Google Slides

posts.name: Daniel
posts.cooked: What’s the main method of fabrication your team uses (ex: CNC, dro mill, etc)? My team never used drawings but that was mainly due to the fact that 98% of our robot parts were COTS, fabricated on a CNC router, 3D printed, or extremely simple. If we were fabbing all our parts on the mill it would’ve been a different story.

posts.name: Spencer
posts.cooked: Our go-to tools are drill presses and shop-scale bandsaws. We primarily rely on hand tools for assembly tasks, while a small group of students operates manual mills equipped with digital readouts (DROs). Recently, we obtained several non-functional 3D printers, hoping to resume operation before the 2026 season.

posts.name: Isaac Proctor
posts.cooked: We literally made a technical drawing for every single part. Including COTS parts

When answering for 3863, we made drawings when feeling extreme but 99% of the time just referenced the CAD when making parts. We used an Onshape classroom organized into folders for the 2025 season (including prototype models, misc parts, etc.) and a subfolder specifically for robot documents (master document plus subsystems). Additionally, we visited FRCDesign.org, an excellent resource containing more information than one could possibly seek.

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked: We create detailed drawings for intricate machine parts, typically made from specific materials and sizes. For most cylindrical components like pipes and shafts, a simple cut list suffices since they're defined by standard dimensions. However, parts that exceed typical stock types or require precise measurements beyond a single dimension necessitate full engineering drawings.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
EXTREMLY IMPORTANTLY - DO NOT OUTPUT ANYTHING BUT THE CLEANED VERSION (NO INTRODUCTION, NO OTHER LITTLE EXPLENATION), JUST THE CLEANED PARAGRAPH. 

I keep the drawing in my head, scrap 3 parts, then do it properly and print out the drawing. Works every time XD
